My Creative Writing Essay

Passive Schizophrenic

Every single one of us have some sort of evil inside; another person, hiding in the shadows of our psyche. There is a mental border of control and sanity. But what happens when that border is crossed?

It was Sunday, May the thirtieth. I got up at around eight and had gone to Church with the family, just as I had every other Sunday of my life. I’m not a religious person but have never had a problem with exploring religions. You see, I am Agnostic; someone who doesn’t believe in a God, but doesn’t doubt the existence of one either. This day, however, would change my life forever. I still often ponder that, if a God does exist, He must have intended for this to happen. But why?

I had never seen her at Church before. But this was not the only reason I noticed her. She looked like an angel; eyes that could burn a thousand holes into anyone’s heart, and a smile that could melt it. She was sitting in the corner, about three metres away from me. Every now and then I would glance in her direction. I couldn’t help myself. Finally, after about an hour I muscled up the confidence to talk to her. “Hi, I’m Jonathan” I said staring right into her eyes.
“Hey, I’m Melissa” she replied. Right then and there I felt my heart skip a beat. She had the sweetest voice I had ever heard.
“Are you new to this church?” I asked.
“Yeah, my mom and I moved here a week ago” she replied followed by a gorgeous smile.
We chatted for a while and I really took an interest in her.
After church she asked me, “Would you like to come around to my place for a swim later on?”
I didn’t hesitate to answer. “Sure. What time? And where do you live?”
She melted my heart again with that stunning smile and said “Anytime after three will be great. My house is number twenty-eight Eastwood Road.”
I couldn’t believe it; she only lived four houses away from mine.

I made my way over to her house at about five minutes to three. I wanted to make a good impression. At exactly three I knocked on her door. She opened the door wearing the most amazing bikini I had ever seen. It was royal-blue in colour with black and white flowers printed on it. Actually, come to think of it, it wasn’t really the most amazing piece of swimwear I had ever seen, but the fact that she was wearing it made it seem like it was at the time. She introduced me to her mom. She was a tall and attractive lady, and I could see where Melissa got her looks from. After being introduced we went over to the pool.
We spent nearly four hours in the pool talking about anything and everything: where we have been, what we would like to do and favourite things of all time. We soon discovered how much we had in common. After getting out of the pool our hands looked like they had aged about fifty years and she handed me a towel to dry myself with. We went inside and, wanting to seem like the most polite kid on the block, I offered to make us a cup of coffee. After we drank the coffee I decided that it was getting a bit late and that it was time to go home. I didn’t want to go home. I wanted to stay there forever. She gave me her number and I left. When I got home, I felt like calling her. But I didn’t; I didn’t want to seem desperate.

We spent the first six months getting to know each other and we became very close friends. The three years that followed was a time of love, friendship and many tears. I thought not even death could have ever hoped to destroy our friendship. I loved her in a way a brother would love his sister; and perhaps a little more. I am an only child, so I could never truly understand that kind of bond; but I think this brought me pretty close.
We would always talk about everything: our problems, people we have an interest in etc. But I never told her how I felt about her. I couldn’t, it would change everything between us, and I would lose the sister I never really had. Throughout the three and a half years that we were friends I saw her go through many relationships. Every single one of them ended up hurting her, and that hurt me too. I would never have hurt her; I’d have made her the happiest girl alive. I didn’t think that there could ever be anything worse than staring into the eyes of the one you love, seeing all that hurt and pain, but knowing that there wasn’t anything I could really do about it. Her last relationship in particular hurt me dearly.

She had been dating a guy by the name of Steven Jenkins. He was 2 years older than her and seemed like a nice guy. But I always got this feeling that there’s another side to him. They dated for nearly a year and she said she was madly in love with him and was convinced that he loved her too.
“I love him so much I gave myself to him” she once said.
Those words hurt me the most, because I never thought that there could have been anyone else in existence capable of loving her more than I did. She later became pregnant and Steven ‘ordered’ her to get an abortion. But she refused. She believed that abortion was the same as murder. They constantly fought, and I would often find myself offering my shoulder for her to cry on. As time progressed the arguments became more intense until one day; he struck her. I only saw her about a week after it had happened; her arm still covered with the bruise. She managed to convince herself that it had been her fault and that she was asking for it. I never really understood that. I simply could not comprehend how a man could ever hit a woman.

I spent the next few months watching her belly grow. I was absolutely fascinated by the process. The doctors had told her that she was bearing a little boy. She would often allow me to place my hand on her belly so I could feel him move inside her. Perhaps he could feel me too; perhaps he could feel my love growing for him as I had felt him grow. I sometimes found my thoughts wondering off, fantasizing about the day the he was to be born, with me at Melissa’s side; holding her hand, being there every step of the way. I would dream about us getting married and taking care of him together; loving him as I did now; as if he were my own. Throughout this time Melissa and Steven’s arguments grew more aggressive, like a cancer, refusing to give up. I could never really understand why they were still together. But she was adamant that they still loved each other. Then, he struck her again. This time it was worse; she ended up in hospital. We contacted the police and gave a statement. He was taken into custody but soon released after his father bailed him out. I’d had enough of it, and decided to confront him.

The next day I saw him at school. He was with some of his friends.
“Now you listen to me very carefully,” I began, “if you ever touch her again, you’ll be signing your death warrant and engraving your name on your headstone.”
He looked at me for a second, and simply smiled. I was about to turn around when he landed a hard right hander on my chin. I hit the floor so hard I could feel my brain rattle in my head like the tail of a Diamondback snake. He walked away, leaving me behind, lying on the ground holding my head firmly. I laid there for about 10 minutes and waited for my head to stop spinning. I proceeded to walked home. Upon my arrival my mom immediately noticed the bruise on my chin and the bump on my head.
She asked me what happened but I simply answered, “Nothing”.

Then, on the evening of November the fourteenth, I received a call from her mom. I knew something was wrong; her mom never called me. I could hear she was crying. I was curious as to what had happened; and then she told me.
“John, Melissa’s dead”.
Those are the last words I ever heard from her again. I felt my knees becoming weak and could no longer support my weight. I dropped to the floor like I had the day Steven punched me. It felt like my whole world had collapsed; and the truth is it did; she was my world. For days I stayed in my room, crying my heart out. I remembered reading a biology textbook in which it explained that our bodies were made up of seventy percent water. I didn’t doubt that anymore, the evidence was soaked up in my pillow.
I decided that I needed to go to her house: the place where I felt true love for the first time. I still thought of it as her house, not as a crime scene, because I could still feel her presence; it was her house, and she was still there. The police were still investigating the area and after much pleading they allowed me to go inside, with the condition that an officer would escort me to make sure that I didn’t disturb any of the evidence. The officer told me that the police believed she had been raped and murdered while her mom was out shopping. I walked up the stairs and towards her room. I had never been in her room before, but it felt like I had. On her dressing table was a photo. It had a metal frame, in the shape of a heart, with the words “Best Friends” engraved on it. The photo inside it was of me and her which she took on the day we went to the beach. I felt my throat getting tight and I found it difficult to swallow. In her room was evidence of an argument and a struggle. I stood there, gazing at the room in which she took her last breath; and then I saw it. Sticking out from under her bed lay a broken bracelet. I quickly grabbed it while the officer wasn’t looking and put it in my pocket. I thanked the police and proceeded to go home. I went straight to my room to examine the bracelet. I had seen it before. On the inside read the name “Steven”. For weeks I sat in my room, still grieving, but planning my revenge.

One Saturday night I went to bed early and waited for my parents to go to bed. I then snuck out to my dad’s garage and found a shovel. I felt that I had to avenge Melissa’s death. I went to find Steven. I knew where to find him. He was at the usual bar, Tempo’s. It’s where he was every Saturday night. The night was cold, and in the distance I could hear the music coming from the bar. A cat, black as the night, and black as my heart walked towards me. His eyes fixed on me as if he knew my intentions. I found an alley from where I could see the bar. I made myself comfortable and waited. After about three hours Steven finally came out. He was alone. I waited until he walked passed the alley so I could run up behind him; and so I did.

I hit him over the head with the shovel; not once, not twice, but an amount which I lost count of.
At first he was screaming “Stop! Stop!”, but I couldn’t; I wasn’t in control.
It felt like something had taken over my body, conducting my every move as if I were a puppet. The more he screamed and struggled the harder I hit. There was blood everywhere, but I didn’t care. He killed me inside, he deserved to be punished. I had crossed that border of control and sanity, and there was no turning back. After some time his cries for help had stopped; the struggling seized. I knew he was dead. I had hit him so many times, I couldn’t lift my arms.
I took a moment to catch my breath. I turned his body over and stared into his lifeless eyes. I felt this inner peace knowing I had accomplished what I set out to do. I sat next to his body, still looking at his eyes. I sat there for quite some time, gazing upon my victory; his corpse my trophy. I found a dustbin in the alley in which I could place his body. It took me a few attempts as the wheels on the dustbin kept rolling backwards, throwing the dustbin onto its side. I placed the bin next to a wall to avoid this and finally managed to place the body in it. But then, not far away, I heard voices. I quickly hid behind the bin.
“What the heck is this?” someone asked.
“It looks like blood” another answered.
“This was it,” I thought, “they’re going to find me”
“We should contact the police immediately” a voice said again.

It was quiet, I didn’t know if they were still there. I took a quick glance around the bin, but no one was there. I had to act fast.
I quickly took the bin over to a nearby park. A must have been roughly half way there when, in the distance, I noticed a pair of distinctive flashing red and blue lights approaching me. I ran, still pushing the bin as fast as I could. The lights were approaching faster and faster. I ducked behind a bush and waited for the car to pass. My heart was pacing in sequence with the revs of the engine approaching me. It came closer and closer. The once silent night was suddenly shattered by a loud SCREEEEETCH as the car slammed on brakes. Through the leaves of the bush I could see the car.
Moments later, I heard the driver shout, “You stupid cat!”
“Thank God!” I thought to myself.
The car drove off again. I sat behind the bush, waiting to see if there were any other dangers coming my way. There was none. I rushed to the park, faster than before.

Once I arrived after a time which seemed like an eternity I proceeded towards the North end of the park. There had been some renovations taking place there two weeks prior. I found the newly renovated garden along with a fresh new flower bed; completely out of sight and not a single source of light apart from the moon which gave me enough light to see what I was doing. I decided that this is where he would remain. I carefully removed the newly planted flowers and I began to dig with the shovel. I dug for about two hours to make sure the hole was deep enough, when suddenly; I heard the sound of leaves being crushed. I stood completely still, hardly a single breathe escaping from my mouth. I heard it again, this time louder, much closer. Then, from under one of the bushes appeared a small, furry black being. I let out a sigh of relief. It was a cat; the same cat that I had encountered before, and perhaps even the same cat that had jumped in front of the police vehicle. I recognized his eyes, once again, fixed on me just as before. After staring at this curious creature for a few seconds I continued with the disposal of the body. I pushed the dustbin, which still contained the body, in the hole and covered it with earth. I replaced the flowers and took a step back. It was perfect; no sign of disturbance whatsoever. I waited patiently to see if anyone had seen me. No one did. I made my way back home and snuck back into the house to find my parents still fast asleep having not noticed that I had been gone. They got up at eight and we all went to church; the very place I had met her.

That day I buried Melissa’s killer along with my love for her. It’s been almost five years now and no one has ever found him. Flyers with his photo were sent out and posters were put up with the hope that someone will come forward with some information. But no one did, no one could; I was the only one who really knew what happened.
We all have an inner evil; it's just that often we are unaware of it until that time comes when something within us snaps. That's what sends us over the edge; to the other side of sanity. Love, jealousy, anger and rage are just some of the emotions that we feel and think we control, but there are moments when we lose grip over what we control. What we control becomes something that controls us.
On that horrible night I met my inner evil; the other person whom I never even knew existed. But he did, and he was as real as the love I felt for Melissa. He scared me, and I hope I never have to meet him again. It has changed my life forever. Wherever I go, I’m always on the run; not from the authorities, but from the evil; from myself.
